commitResults.messageTitle: Modify chatbot name, create default greeting & farewell message
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot had a generic name

A generic name makes the chatbot less memorable
and engaging

Modifying its name gives more personality to
the chatbot

Let's
* implement a default greet and farewell function
* give the chatbot a unique name

Abstracting the default greet and farewell messages
allows the main function to follow SLAP principle

Dippy did not have any interactive functionality.

A chatbot without any interaction with the user
provides very little value.

Let's
* display instructions after the greeting message
* collect user input from standard input
* allow user to type (nearly) anything and control
  where their input ends
* echo the user input back to standard output

User needs clear instructions to know how to interact
with the chatbot.
The user input can consist of multiple lines, since a
chatbot that can only accepts one line at a time is
unlikely to be appealing to users.
Echoing user input to standard output shows that the
chatbot is able to collect and parse user input
correctly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Added ASCII art to greeting message

commitResults.messageBody:
Dippy is only able to echo back user input.

Echoing back user input does not provide much
value for users.

Let's
* allow users to add items to a list
* allow users to view the items they have added
  to the list

The list is declared in the scope of the execute()
function because in the future, different execute
functions may require different data structures

Dippy can only record items that the user provided.

It would provide more value if the items represent
something that the user would want to keep track of
and modify the behaviour of

Let's
* represent Tasks as the items
* lets the user add Tasks, mark Tasks as done, and
  view Tasks

Tasks are declared as a separate class to utilise
encapsulation to represent a Task with its attributes
and methods

Dippy can only handle one type of simple
tasks without much attributes assigned to
them.

Dippy should be able to manage different
types of tasks with different attributes to
be more helpful.

Let's
* implement deadline task with a deadline date
* implement event task with a start and end
  date
* lets users customise the dates of the tasks
  that they create

Inheritance is used because different types of
tasks still have common attributes. Moreover,
changes to Task class will also ripple down to
children classes for convenience.

Dippy currently does not generate feedback to users if the user gives invalid input.

This makes Dippy confusing to use for users.

Let's

* implement error handling for empty todo description
* implement error handling for unknown commands

All exceptions related to Dippy are subclasses of DippyException, so that they inherit
the behaviours and properties of DippyException.

Inherited subclasses generate more specific error messages so that they are as
informative to the user as possible, so that Dippy guides the user on how to
interact with Dippy correctly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Implement the ability to delete tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Dippy could accumulate tasks, but could not remove tasks.

In order to improve task management, deleting tasks is
an essential feature.

Let's
* allow for a 'delete' command to delete the task at the
  index specified by the user

Using an ArrayList allowed for automatic array resizing
while still enabling random access, making for an efficient
delete operation.
